sanskrit: द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते | सौभद्रыш्च महाबाहुः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान् || 4|| धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान् | पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः || 5|| युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तामौजाश्च वीर्यवान् | सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व योद्धा महारथाः || 6||
Translation: Drupada and the sons of Draupadi, and Saubhadra, the mighty-armed, blew their conch shells. Dhristaketu, Chekitana, the king of Kashiraja, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and the brave Shaibya. Yudhamanyu, the brave Uttamaujas, the son of Subhadra, and the sons of Draupadi, all great charioteers.
answer: In the Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 1, verses 4-6, Duryodhana mentions several warriors from the Pandava army. The warriors mentioned include: Drupada and the sons of Draupadi, Subhadra's son (Abhimanyu, also known as Saubhadra), Dhristaketu, Chekitana, Kashiraja, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, Shaibya, Yudhamanyu, Uttamaujas, and the five sons of Draupadi. These verses demonstrate the strength and prowess of the Pandava army, with many skilled and powerful warriors ready to fight.
